title: Will the government of Colombia and the FARC sign a final peace agreement before 1 May 2016?
preds: No chance. Peace talks missed deadline for final deal earlier in month.
Think they'll strike a deal, just not by May 1...

Just four days to go.....http://www.newsweek.com/farc-rebel-rehab-hopes-create-lasting-peace-colombia-451620  ...."Peace talks in Havana missed a March 23 deadline, but both sides have said they believe a deal can be reached by the end of the year."

From a Newsweek article on 4/24:
"Peace talks in Havana missed a March 23 deadline, but both sides have said they believe a deal can be reached by the end of the year. Even if the talks collapse, the government plans to continue the demobilization program. Already, there are some metrics to prove its success: Of the 49,000 people who have entered the program, more than 25,000 have learned to read and write, and 12,000 have reintegrated into society with the full rights of a Colombian citizen, according to the Agency for Reintegration." http://www.newsweek.com/farc-rebel-rehab-hopes-create-lasting-peace-colombia-451620
According to general news and GJP consensus, and only 1 week away.
The FARC is dragging this negotiation for at least another year
The conversations have been stalling thanks to recent FARC aggressions

While most conflicts with guerilla groups have ceased and ended peacefully, the only Latin American guerrilla movement that was both involved in the drug trade, and is no longer active, had the backing of another world government government. Many of the Latin American guerilla movements that were involved in drugs, and crime in general, are still active; while more political, less criminal movements tend to end.
Recent News on the Peace Talks :  http://colombiareports.com/farc-rebels-seek-popes-intervention-colombias-peace-talks/

I don't believe that the government of Columbia and the FARC will sign a final peace agreement before May 2016. My reasoning for believing this is that the FARC has been leading the government on for years, and although they have come close and agreed on certain aspects of the peace treaty, i don't believe the agreement will ever be solidified through the actual signing of a peace agreement by May 1st, 2016.
According to general news and GJP consensus, and only 2 weeks away.
Time is running out on this one.
Adjusting for the passage of time.
lowering due to short time remaining.

maintaining 0%.  As I reevaluate this question I started out at 7% owing my low forecast to FARC culture and their symbols of cultural identity which ultimately brought me to a no "final" peace deal would be signed.  But then an announcement of President Obama and Sec Kerry would be visiting Cuba a couple days before the FARC/Columbia self imposed deadline for a "final peace deal" and I could not ignore the significance of this visit.  I really thought this could be accomplished and a final peace deal would be signed.  I over estimated two of the four (DIME) powers of American power; Diplomacy and Economics. We still have time left on this GJ question...not ruling out some kind of a deal but there will not be a "final deal".
According to general news and GJP consensus.
Yeah I think they're bored of the fighting
@praedico points out probably correctly that a cease-fire is not likely a "final peace agreement."

Only 10 days ago we were reading that the talks had "stalled" because of "major setbacks" (http://www.breitbart.com/national-security/2016/03/31/amid-floundering-farc-peace-talks-colombia-announces-similar-talks-terrorist-eln-group/).

now they say they are days away. http://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Colombia-FARC-Peace-Talks-Just-Days-Away-from-Cease-fire-Deal-20160410-0028.html. Time is running out but i feel like we have to take them at their word

While a "final peace agreement" still may be a long shot, things seem to be moving slowly in that direction.
http://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Colombia-FARC-Peace-Talks-Just-Days-Away-from-Cease-fire-Deal-20160410-0028.html
According to general news reports and gjp consensus.

Peace talks currently going nowhere; FARC issue on right wing paramilitaries (ie., state sponsored militias) contests government denials causing lack of movement.
See details :  http://colombiareports.com/paramilitary-threat-puts-farc-peace-talks-hold/
resolution of differences "Almost Certainly Not Likely"
Just catching up to this.  They missed the deadline.  They're close, but not logistically close, so an extra month won't make that much difference.

After missing the March 23 deadline, both FARC and the Colombian government said they were still working on the negotiations and that they were not going to sign an agreement just to meet a deadline.  Sec of State John Kerry met with the FARC while in Cuba and also met with representatives from the Colombian government. All seemed optimistic the peace deal is in the final stages but the date of May 1 is coming too soon. I will lower the forecast significantly as it is the deal is not likely to be signed by the end date.
Decreasing the probability from 30% to 15%, simply because time is running out fast.
Lowering based on lack of progress.

Too little time to sort out the details and the unpopular president Santoz is not going to rush it even with the support of the US.  Santos would probably like to have a peace deal as a legacy but I don't think it's going to happen in the next month.

Mr. Obama was invited by FARC and Columbia  to work out a final peace agreement, which was one of the reasons he went to Cuba. to meet with them. The 'road map' was built over the past few years,  after 60 years of conflict, which included areas such as agriculture distribution, gender equality, economic assistance, post-conflict legal strategies, etc. The Obama administration also sold Columbia a number of modern weapon technologies to defeat FARC and ELN, the later group recently opening communication to join the peace agreement. 
The peace talks were delayed recently and it is unlikely that the agreement will become signed by the forecast. 
1. Mr. Santos popularity has fallen since the talks between his administration and FARC. Without strong numbers, his administration may not have the support of the government or the voters.
2. Demonstrations on the street by Right Wing groups who do not support the talks.
3.The Right Wing paramilitary, drug dealers, Conservative lawmakers both past and now, who do not support the talks, 
4. A vote by the Colombian people to accept the agreement. 
5. The FARC and ELN supporters want guarantees that their safety is not impeded upon by Conservative leaders with alliances to Right Wing death squads and other paramilitary or drug gangs, 
6. Pockets of resistance in FARC and ELN that do not want the talks to continue without further demands and rights.
7. The US senate has to agree upon a foreign aid package and, given the climate of the Senate, their record is to obfuscate and obstruct policies from the Obama administration.

With less than a month left until the end of this question, it appears that a final peace agreement will not be in place by that time. Examples of other government-rebel peace discussions that missed deadlines do not provide distinct trends for the length of negotiations after a missed deadline. Additionally, commentators on the FARC peace negotiations range in their belief that the sides will come to agreement, with some saying as early as June and others saying by the end of 2016. Additionally, it is not clear how often negotiations are being held at this time or what the announcement of the ELN talks will do to the FARC discussions. Despite that, the length of the negotiations thus far, and the outstanding issues including still getting a ceasefire agreement, provide little reassurance that they will be completed within the timeline of the question.
Oh-uh, this went terribly stale. Time is running out.

Santos would like to sign an agreement and have a chance to win the Nobel Peace Prize.  The leaders of the FARC do not want to give up their drug business and are used to living on the fringes of society.  There's a chance for an agreement but it's low probability.

With talks between the Colombian Government and ELN, the negotiation process on two fronts (with formidable enemies) it is reasonable to expect that the signing of a final peace agreement will be extended for some time.  It is unlikely that a negotiation strategy by the Colombian government will take two paths for each rebel/guerilla contestation.  The negotiations in fact will become more complicated and protracted in that the negotiations will need to take account for the demands & concessions of three parties.   Conflict between FACR and ELN has a long history along with their cooperation with the Colombian government over time.  A final negotiated solution would require a meeting of minds in compromise as well as a stabilized demobilization plan (which is currently the most difficult of all issues).  Demands by any side would have to renegotiated where agreement has previously reached.   The larger the size of the negotiation group, the larger the number of interactions are required to get to a signed peace accord.   May 2016 might still be too early to reach a settlement among the parties.

They may sign an agreement ,it will not be a complete peace agreement by 1 May 2016. I was a real optimist a while ago,  but I think  it will take longer.offcourse any thing is possible in Colombia but It seems the leaders may delay final agreement.
I think in South America we are a bit more relaxed and dates usually get delayed any ways . Importance is reaching the agreement not a set date. It may take a bit longer. Pledges are for publicity and a line in the sand. A fitting  date would be the international workers day on May 1. So possible as far as the symbolism  but unlikely in reality. Those are my thoughts currently .

The Colombian Interior Minister Juan Fernando Cristo said earlier this month that the Colombian government would meet with the leaders of FARC to sign a peace deal...but not until May. Considering that political events never really occur before a given timeline, and in the case of such a contentious matter (a government making final amends with a guerrilla group), an agreement would take some time following any initial meeting. And this is assuming that it would happen.

Don't know much about Latin Am. Following some experienced forecasters on this one.
They mist the last deadline for a peace deal on March 23. There will also be a popular vote on the peace agreement. So there is simply not 	enough time.

Dateline 3-23-16 Colombia’s government and left-wing FARC rebels missed the March 23 deadline for the signing of a peace agreement. While peace was not obtained, some progress has been made in the past six months.
Lowering sharply due to missed deadline.

This is looking much less likely than the 15% I originally gave it, partly because of the missed deadline today. There is progress, and there will probably eventually be an agreement, but perhaps not as soon as was hoped. http://colombiapeace.org/2016/03/23/why-colombias-negotiators-couldnt-manage-a-cease-fire-by-march-23/
Kerry's recent meeting in Cuba is being presented as a step forward, but the negotiations are still far apart on key issues according to various news sources.
hedging down further. any final deal would be a huge surprise at this point. @cmeinel

"US Secretary of State John Kerry has urged the Colombian government and the Farc rebels to redouble their efforts to reach a peace accord."
- http://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-35868451
I've been high on this, so coming down because I'm afraid the "referendum" will delay the final agreement signing.

The Colombian government, one of the U.S. closest allies in the hemisphere, has been negotiating with the FARC for months in an effort to reach a deal which Colombians would have to approve in a referendum. There are a few points yet to be ironed out. The two most important ones are the scope and pace of FARC disarmament, which would be supervised by the UN, and who and how many FARC senior officers and would have to stand trial for crimes they have ordered, and how many senior officers would receive amnesty.
Colombian President Juan Manuel Santos and FARC leader Rodrigo “Timochenko” Londono have set a March 23 deadline to reach a comprehensive peace agreement, but have since admitted that goal may not be realistic.
http://www.homelandsecuritynewswire.com/dr20160321-john-kerry-to-meet-leaders-of-colombia-s-farc-guerillas-in-cuba-today

staying with consensus
http://www.wola.org/commentary/colombia_s_peace_process_ensuring_the_success_of_a_potential_bilateral_ceasefire_agreemen
differentiates between what will occur on March 23 & final peace accord, which is anticipated mid-year.
No. Half measures are degenerating into "quarter measures." Trust is ebbing and Castro regime is bullish on supporting FARC and its proxies in neighboring nations.
"Now that a historic peace accord with leftist FARC guerrillas could be signed within weeks, Colombia’s government is eager to ensure ties to the US military endure in a post-conflict future."

Colombia FARC peace process to receive 450m in US aid, the two sides still have a great deal of mistrust and will not meet the March 26 deadline for an official agreement. First the terrorist organizations connections to the drug money will not just disappear; Colombia is the world's top producer of cocaine. The terms for disarming the group will not happen inasmuch as the rebels still hold that the police or government security forces exists as corrupt. Even when an agreement can be signed the greatest number of the leadership will transfer to the lesser terrorist group ELN which exists more ideological than the FARC, nevertheless the two groups have similar programs.
Reducing probability due to the passage of time.
postponing and confirming no deal on 3/23 means they will not sign one a month later either. I had high hopes for this one...
"Santos sends brother to Cuba to break deadlock in FARC peace talks
Effort to have a signable agreement in Havana for Obama's visit seem to have come up just short of the finish line.

A final peace deal is starting to look as though it will eventually be in reach, unfortunately I do not believe such negotiations can be finalized in such a short period of time. Peace will not be finalized if the issue of amnesty and extradition remains open. It will take a while for the Colombian Congress to draft legislation that would legalize such measures within the transitional courts. It should be noted that the Santos Government would have simple majority support if it decides to push for amnesty and non-extradition and a simple majority is all that is required to pass such legislation. Also, 8 FARC members were just arrested, and I believe this will hinder progress more than help it. (Unless those arrested are high ranking enough to be used as bargaining chips to draw major concessions from the FARC. Initial reports don't indicate this to be the case though)
Down again due to signs of delays in negotiations. Both parties have declared that complying with deadlines is no longer a priority. Further, no tentative dates have been accorded.
It looks like the talks may fall apart, best case the negotiations could drag on for far longer than anyone expected.
peace deal signing delayed.  new date not established

The President of Colombia, Juan Manuel Santos, and the leadership of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) have confirmed that the two will not sign a peace deal on March 23 that would have allowed FARC leaders to return to Colombia as previously planned.

diving -12
"“It seems to us that President Santos acted objectively and we agree with what he said, that there are not conditions for the 23rd,” said FARC peace negotiator Joaquin Gomez on Thursday in reference to the impending self-imposed deadline at the end of this month. The statement comes after Santos admitted for the first time on Wednesday that the talks will not wrap up before March 23 and that the government is not willing to sign a deal prematurely just in order to meet the deadline.
. . .
"But despite the progress, the much anticipated March 23 deadline, whose hype was amped up by the planned visit by U.S. President Barack Obama in Colombia from March 20 to 22, has been deemed impossible. The U.S. has long financed Colombia's counterinsurgency strategy against the FARC. No new date has been set publicly for when Colombia can now expect to announce the end of five decades of civil war and the beginning of peace."
(http://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Peace-on-Hold-in-Colombia-as-FARC-Govt-Extend-Negotiations-20160310-0049.html)

Both sides seem willing to take this monumental step by the March 23 deadline. Whether or not the people later ratify this is less certain but an agreement seems fairly likely.

The Catholic Church will sponsor a final peace agreement between the government of Colombia and FARC to be signed on Easter Day. This will serve to underline its involvement in the agreement, and to draw on the support of religious elements in the leadership of both parties.
First half of the year is not so important in South America. After winter, real negotiations will begin.

Santos is committed to make it happen. Has even ask Dept of State to remove FARC from the terrorist list. A few hurdles, the compensation to the victims, the minimun salaries for FARC, the weapons turned to Venezuela. High chance they will miss Marc deadline but still make it by May.

17% down relative to my latest forecast mainly due to the following:
a. Latin American governments, in general, struggle heavily to meet deadlines. This will not be the exception.
b. If there is a document before may 1st, 2016. It will doubtfully be a final one. Since FARC has already said that there are substantial 'holes'  in the negotiating process and they have incentives to delay the agreement as much as possible to get the most out of government pressure and urgency to sign the agreement.
c. FARC members have violated the protocols of the agreement already, which adds up to the latter comment.
d. There's still a referendum to be taking place in Colombia. Conditional to the agreement, the people in Colombia would have to accept it as final. Its hard to imagine that not having even the final agreement on sight.
Down 40% @ulfelder and others. I suspect there may be something before this date, but suspect it would be a stretch to consider it "final."

FARC pushes back date for final Colombia peace treaty
Mar 03,2016
HAVANA, March 2 (Xinhua) -- The hope of reaching a final peace agreement between Colombian government and the FARC guerrilla movement in March has gone up in flames after envoys to peace talks in Havana stated Wednesday this would not happen before the end of the year.

It looks like FARC really wants this. Its most strenuous objection to the negotiations so far seems to be the intention of Pres. Santos to call a referendum. But my understanding is that this will be a non-binding plebescite. It seems that Santos is often criticized for strong-arming whatever he wants through the legislature, so the plebiscite is a gesture to public opinion. The other issue is the United States' list of terrorist organizations and threats to extradite about 50 FARC members wanted on drug trafficking charges. Santos has prevented extradition in the past, but it's unclear if he will be able to get a blanket commitment from the US not to pursue it. US has said that FARC will not be removed from terrorist list until after they give up arms, so the order in which things need to be done may be an obstacle. Even so, if Santos can get some promises from the US, and the FARC negotiators trust him, there could be an agreement before May.

President Juan Manuel Santos and Las Farc leadership did not reach common ground on the path-to-peace. The government intends to consult the public on the path-to-peace terms via a referendum (plebiscito refrendatorio), and Las Farc leadership argues that this is not part of the cease-fire agreement and is unconstitutional. So, the government will take some time to delineate the agreeement (and have it reviewed by judicial authorities), align it with las Farc leadership, organise and perform the referendum, make results public and (in case las Farc does not raise any complaints) proceed with the transitional program. That is a lot of work to get done in a 2.5 months time window.

Initial forecast. Many have called for an extension of the March 23 "deadline", the government will probably stay silent on dates until mid-march. The extension could be of a couple of months (for a variety of reasons it cannot be longer), so the 50% present consensus is about right, yet news about new negotiators from the urban guerrilla network at the same time that urban unrest is on the rise makes me weary of a fast resolution:
http://caracol.com.co/radio/2016/02/09/nacional/1455033660_899781.html

The Colombian Peace talks are beset with significant substantive problems regarding the integration of its paramilitary force, the question of its ownership and share of 60% of cocaine production and distribution (a significant financial asset that FARC is unlikely to give up), and previously stalled negotiations over the last 5 years.   Leading negotiators for FARC have indicated publicly in Cuba during its recent negotiations with the Colombian ruling government that its (government) of a March deadline to complete all outstanding issues in the negotiations is naive, unreasonable and illusive.   A significant component yet to negotiated is the creating and establishment (which all agree would take at least a decade or more) of a sustainable economy in the FARC controlled territory among the landless, peasants and other classes.  Its illusive tasks are made difficult in that it needs to find an economy that can sustain and surpass the economic benefits of a narcoterrorist economy (cocaine).  With the additional two month requirement established by this question (beyond March) does not make an agreement more possible;  beside agreement substantively differs from signing an agreement.  The Colombian government is still beset with problems of regarding the ELN (a major guerilla organization) with whom it has no history of negotiations.   This dispels the fantasy that ongoing conflict interactions between it and the government, it and FARC could present significantly more dangers to a peace process, were it to be achieved.  So the question remains, given the status quo, or a move to FARC agreement and military integration, and the creation of an economy that is able to sustain a large population of FARC supporters and members in its territory, will peace move Colombia into an abyss much more aggressive than it current status.  At this posting, escalation in military conflict continues between the government and the ELN.

Government has incentives to comply with the agreed date (March 23th). However, given the nature of the conflict and the difficulties on agreeing, and the usual tendency to not comply with deadlines by Latin American governments, I would say that it is unlikely they sign the agreement by this date. 
In addition, FARC leaders have said that, in their view, "it is almost impossible" to comply with the due date due to important holes in the current negotiations. Further, FARC leaders don't care much about deadlines and, even though this might increase their negotiating power, I'm not sure to what extent the Colombian government is ready to grant them at the expense of complying with deadlines. 
I believe chances are good the agreement will be signed this year, so I'm considering the agreement could be signed any day of 2016.

The parties set a March 23 deadline, and while one side (FARC) essentially called that “naïve,” resolution by the forecasting question (May 1) seems promising following a Santos visit to Washington, Obama’s commitment of increase funding (albeit in fiscal year 2017, which does not being until October 1), the release of prisoners by Santos, and a UNSC verification/monitoring commitment, which both sides requested. However, I think a survey of history would suggest that an agreement of this magnitude slips even further. I tried to find some analysis on analogous situations (e.g., Northern Ireland), but didn’t discover. Therefore, I don’t have data to evaluate my hypothesis, but I’m willing to let it inform my forecast nonetheless. I think a peace agreement will be reached sometime this year, but given the comments and reactions since December, I think this is likely to go past May 1. Deadlines can harden positions as much as they can encourage resolution, and I think typically deadlines encourage resolution when a powerful third party is establishing them. There are a number of interested external parties, the US foremost among them, but I don't know if the Obama Administration has the bandwidth to midwife this peace agreement by May 1.

As of Oct 2015, 46% of Columbians were optimistic that the peace talks would succeed. At that time, both parties agreed on over 80% of the peace terms. Both parties say that they are close to a deal. However, FARCs negotiator in Cuba has already said that the March 23rd date is extremely unlikely, even though the government seems to be pushing for this date. An important point is that the talks cover a series of 6 points and only 3 of these points have reached partial agreements. The three remaining points are the treatment of victims, the end of conflict (including the standing down of both FARC soldiers and paramilitary groups) and finally implementation. These points are tricky and may be very difficult to manage.

The President will be hosting President Santos this week and it seems this will be an issue of much importance. Too much many spent throughout the years in Columbia to allow a deal, that is so close, fall apart.

The conflict between FARC and the Columbian Government is complex, been ongoing for years and deadly. Whilst peace talks started in 2012 there has been some progress with a new deadline of 23 Mar 16. This is a key date to watch and will determine whether the May deadline is achievable. The talks looks positive with the recent UN Security Council approving a mission to monitor the talks if a deal is signed.
